texts.definition: The goal to avoid being captured or hit.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal to avoid being captured or hit.</style>

Many games have dangers that need to be avoided. <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> is the goal to try and avoid these dangers, regardless if they are due to "natural" causes such as falling rocks or intentional attacks such as weapon fire.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> gives an example of a turn-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style> in which <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> occurs. When playing this game, players may have groups that will be captured unless they manage to <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> an enclosure constructed by another player. <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals can also occur in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, either as "optional goals" when any piece is threatened or as enforced goals when one's king is checked.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Arcade%20Games">Arcade Games</link></style> had <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals as a main part of their gameplay: in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> one much avoiding ghosts while collecting the yellow dots, in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Centipede">Centipede</link></style> one must avoid all enemies while trying to kill the centipede, in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Donkey%20Kong">Donkey Kong</link></style> barrels need to be avoided, and being hit by asteroids in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style> destroys one's ship.

Much of the skill in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unreal%20Tournament%20series">Unreal Tournament series</link></style> consist of avoiding to be hit be enemies.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resident%20Evil%20series">Resident Evil series</link></style> makes use of quick time event challenges to let players evade various dangers in the game.

Creating <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals consist of providing players means of avoiding <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> by doing <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> differs from <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> in that in the former <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> may already know one's locations or <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> may effectively be absent. One such example of absent <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> is provided by <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, and in this case even gameplay <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> may not be necessary if <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> are used instead. Being the target of <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goals already imply that some type of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> exists and that <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> is possible (otherwise, the <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goal would be trivial), so this pattern can be seen as a way of instantiating <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals. Giving <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can be seen as another way of creating <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals which may co-exist with other <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals - here the evasion is done to protect especially vulnerable areas rather than all areas. However, not all <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals exist at the beginning of games. Instead, they can appear as a form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> due to failing with others goals, e.g. <style="Link"><link="scouting">Scouting</link></style>. Paradoxically, successful <style="Link"><link="scouting">Scouting</link></style> can allow players to succeed with <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals if the threat that needs to be evaded is known but isn't threatening to the players yet due to those players being undetected.

Common Penalties linked to failure of Evade goals are Ability Losses, Damage, or the loss of Lives (or Units). Evade goals can seldom be completed in themselves, with the exception of Evade goals with Time Limits, but can often be completed by achieving another goal: that of completing an Excluding Goal to whatever goals cause the actions the player is trying to Evade to be done. Examples of this include shooting Enemies that are trying to shoot one or deactivating robots trying to kill one. Besides being tied to other goals to be fulfilled, Evade goals can be Supporting Goals for Traverse and Deliver goals. Evade patterns often interact with Overcome patterns: there may be no need to succeed with Overcome goals if players can succeed with Evade goals, and vice versa. They also allow players to create tactics of offense and defense, e.g., accepting Gote or trying various gambits to acquire Sente in Go. Explicit interaction between the patterns can be designed by letting players have Evade goal until a certain other goal, e.g. Gain Ownership of a Weapon or acquiring a Power-Up, is completed, and then let them strive for an Overcome goal. This can be used to create Role Reversal patterns, as in Pac-Man where ghost move from having Capture goals to having Evade goals if the player gets hold of a power pill.

While <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> are not necessary for <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals, having them present is likely to make the <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals more difficult. Related to this is using <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> to determine success or failure with <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals but this does not necessarily need to imply the presence of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> can also be used together with or independently of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> to modulate <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals but it is worth noting that this pattern can be used to make <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals both easier and more difficult. Any kind of <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> that affect players during evasion naturally makes <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals more difficult while <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> can make them easier (the opposite can be achieved by giving these to those with <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goals related to the <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals).

<style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals can easily be formalized in games as <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> and thereby create <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can be built from <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can also provide information and motivation for the pattern.

<style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals are based upon avoiding being hit or captured, and therefore naturally promote <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in games. In <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, this typically requires players to be proficient in <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> is often the required skill in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals are <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> that are likely to cause <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> to those that have them due to the clear potential for <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> if they fail. When the evasion has to be done against <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> actions, <style="CurrentLink">Evade</style> goals are <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style>. One such example is to avoid the <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals of others, something which naturally make these goals more difficult. Another example is to avoid those with <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goals - here the use of <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> for one or the other can easily make for <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>
